testimony: We'll proceed with the other one now.  Mr Duma, which language would you prefer to use?
We will follow the same procedure as we followed in the first one.  I've already presented the supplementary affidavit and we have nothing further to add.

Thank you, Mr Chair, just a few questions.
	You say you were requested by Mr Mpo Tseklo(?) to transport his fellow comrades.
Who was Mr Mpo Tseklo and did he belong to any political organisation?
Yes, he was an ANC member, Mpo Tseklo, in Meadowlands, Zone 2.
Besides being a member of the ANC, did he hold any position, was he involved in any activities, was he an active member, can you just give us more information about him?

Yes, Mpo Tseklo was an ANC follower and an activist and he was at school at the time, involved in the school activities as well and the in the forefront in the struggle matters inasfar as school environment was concerned.
Did you say he was an ANC follower or supporter or a member?
Why were you specifically chosen to transport these people?
Mpo chose me because he knew me and I also had a car at that time.
Sorry, were you a member or a follower of the ANC?
I was a follower at that time.
Were you a card-carrying member?  Sorry, are you saying you were a follower?
Before he chose you to transport his fellow comrades, did he used to involve you in other operations?
Although I would not refer to them as operations, but he would refer people to come to me for transport, to assist in things like funerals and things like that which required transport.
Did you know these comrades that you had to transport?
No, I did not know them.  I wasn't quite used to them as such, but I knew them by sight.  Mpo is the one who told me one of them, the name of one of them.
What was the name of that person?
Do you know where he was from?
Yes, he also resided in Meadowlands, Zone 2.
And were you told what they were going to do where you were transporting them to?
Yes, that was told to me.
What were they going to do there?
They were going to fetch firearms, guns.
Exactly where were the arms that they were going to fetch?
Those guns were fetched from Booysen, a certain place in Booysen.
Was it in a house?  Where was this place situated where you had to go and get these firearms?
When we got to Booysen I parked the car next to a scrap yard and they alighted from the car and went inside the scrap-yard and came back after a few minutes with bags full of arms.
Would you be in a position to know where these firearms came from?
As to where they were coming from no, I don't know and as to how they got there I don't know as well.
Cam you briefly tell us how you were caught?

We were arrested on our way back to Soweto with these firearms in the car.  As we approached a certain stop there were police there and they tried to stop us and we stopped.  In fact they stopped us, we stopped and they wanted to - they didn't stop us ...
A point of rectification - we were being stopped, but I did not stop.
I was convicted for unlicensed ammunition and in possession, because I was found also in possession of unlicensed firearms.
As a person who has applied for amnesty, how would you justify your having transported people to go and fetch arms for the ANC?  How would you justify that politically?

There is a correlation between what I did and the political aspect because the violence was rife in the area where we resided and people were killed, attacked left right and centre.   Most of the being who were being attacked and killed were ANC members being attacked by the organisation, IFP, together the police.  Now those things resulted to the community deciding and together with the comrades deciding that we should be able to obtain firearms or weapons rather, to protect the community.  Now that is how this is related to politics, my actions that is.

Thank you, Mr Chair,  no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS THABETE
Mr Motepe, have you got anymore questions?

I don't have anymore questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MOTEPE
On page 68 of the bundle, paragraph 10(a) you say that your political objective was to defend the communities of Meadowlands and Mzimshlope, why did you feel called upon to defend those communities?
To defend the community was a right to every affected party, that something must be done to protect the attacks, the community from attacks.
So that what you chose to do, you chose of your own volition to defend these communities?
Yes, on my own volition I did choose to defend the community of South Africa at large because we were being oppressed at the time.
When you were asked to transport these people, were you paid?
You say you wanted to defend the communities of Meadowlands and Mzimshlope, how were you going to defend these communities?  I still don't understand.

In a way of availing my car to be used for such activities to obtain things that will help us to be able to defend the community, weapons, things like weapons that would have been used by people defending, or in a mission of defending the community.
Were you employed at the time?
No, I was self-employed, I was not employed.
We had at home a fast-food outlet.
For what are you actually applying for amnesty?

I'm applying for amnesty for, especially as we are aware that we are living in a new era here in South Africa, the apartheid has since died and it was a result of apartheid that these things happened and that is in the past now, we are living in the present and the future and we are preaching the gospel of reconciliation here in the country, South Africa that is.  I deemed it fit and appropriate for me to come forward and disclose all the truth to the community of South Africa through this vehicle of TRC, so that they may know better as to what happened.
I think you misunderstand my question, I didn't ask why you are applying for amnesty, I'm asking in respect of what offences.
In respect of my conviction.  I'm in prison now and I'm coming forward ...(intervention)
What, what crime?  What do you want us to do, grant you amnesty for what, in respect of what?
Grant me amnesty because I've been convicted for going to fetch the firearms and attempted murder of some policemen.  Those are the acts I'm seeking amnesty for.
Now that's what I'm getting at.  Most of your testimony concerned the transportation of all these weapons, tell us more about this attempted murder.
To explain briefly, when I was being convicted at the court of law with regard to these cases that I've referred to, they gave me 5 years for attempted murder.
How did you commit this attempted murder?
It was not me who attempted to murder, but people in my company that did that, who were shooting at the police, the people I was transporting.  Because ...(intervention)
While you were escaping from the police?
It is because we had firearms concealed in our car and they were not licensed.
Mr Duma, listen to the question, I'm trying to help you, I'm not trying to catch you out.  You were part of a group of people, some of whom shot at the police, do I understand you correct?
All I'm asking is, was that the time you were driving that motor vehicle escaping from these police?
Yes, I was driving this vehicle when I was escaping from the police.
So although you never actually shot yourself, you were part of that group?
You accepted responsibility for everything that happened on that trip, do I understand you correct?

And you needed these weapons, as far as you were concerned, to defend that community and therefore the police were shot at?  You couldn't allow the police to get hold of those weapons, is that the position?
There was only one count of attempted murder that you were convicted of?
When did that happen, not the conviction, the incident.
Yes, I was asked to transport people who were going to fetch weapons at that particular time.
And that was successful, you did collect weapons?
Yes, we did a successful, except for the time when we came across the policemen.
So when you came across the policemen there were weapons in the car?  That is how I understand your application.
Do you I understand you correctly that when you were asked to assist by transport, you willingly agreed and that was your contribution to the political struggle?
Yes, because I knew the people who were asking me this and I also knew their involvement in the community and I agreed.
When the police tried to stop your car, you drove past, you didn't accede to that command, do I understand you correctly?
When the police tried to stop the car one of the people inside said: "There are the police, don't stop in case they stop you", and indeed I drove past.
Now if you knew it was the police yourself, without being told, would you have stopped or would you have driven on on your own?
As for me I wouldn't have stopped because at the time police were not faithful, I mean you could not trust police.
Were they ordered to run concurrently or were they separate?
May you please repeat your question?
Were those separate sentences ordered to run concurrently or were they kept separate?
So you're only serving that - I see you're in prison clothes, are you still serving that particular 9 year sentence?
Yes, 9 years is part of the entire sentence that I'm serving.
Are you serving other parts of sentence?
The one case that I was convicted for was being suspected of robbing the bank and attempting to steal a car.
Those are independent acts, separate from your application?
Yes, those had nothing to do with this amnesty application.  The other 10 years is still on appeal at court.

Okay.  Yes thank you, you are excused.
WITNESS EXCUSED

Ms Thabete, have you got any evidence?

Can you deal with one aspect. Do you think we can include that should we lean towards granting amnesty?

I think that will be proper in case in future such charges might be brought against him, that that will be proper now to deal with even though it was not specifically mentioned, but they are tied together.
Ja, ja.  It will be based on the same facts, isn't it?

That is correct.
